questions.text: Which of the following substances inhibits oxidative phosphorylation by blocking the transportation of ADP and ATP?
questions.solution:
Atractyloside is a drug, which inhibits the process of oxidative phosphorylation by preventing the transportation of ADP into, and ATP out of, the mitochondria.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic because of walking difficulties. He also has progressive muscle weakness. The examination is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The finding of enlarged calf muscles and atrophied thigh muscles with a history of muscle weakness are suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). 

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the most common hereditary neuromuscular disease. It is an X-linked recessive disorder. In DMD, pseudohypertrophy of the calf muscles occurs due to muscle enlargement by the infiltration of fat. It is weak, unlike the muscle that enlarges due to hypertrophy. Pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles is the characteristic feature of DMD, whereas the other 3 conditions mentioned in the options do not have this feature.

Clinical features:

  1. Progressive weakness with developmental delay
  2. Pseudohypertrophy of calves
  3. Wasting of thigh muscles
  4. Characteristic Trendelenburg gait or hip waddle.
  5. Gower’s sign
  6. Dilated cardiomyopathy

Treatment includes supportive management for cardiac decompensation, nutritional management, physiotherapy, and glucocorticoids. Death usually occurs by 18 to 20 years of age due to respiratory failure, intractable heart failure, pneumonia, or aspiration.

Other options:

Option B: Myotonic dystrophy presents with distal muscle weakness, proximal muscle involvement is very late.

Option C: Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), type 1 (which is most common) presents in infancy. Death occurs early. 

Option D: Myasthenia gravis (MG) is a neuromuscular disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles, due to a decrease in the number of available acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at neuromuscular junctions as a result of antibody-mediated autoimmune attack.

questions.text:
Match the following triage tags with the appropriate traumatic conditions.
Triage tag Condition
1. Black A. Flail chest
2. Red B. Pelvic fracture
3. Green C. Extensive third-degree burns
4. Yellow D. Sprain of the ankle
questions.solution:
The correct option is Option C: 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B.

Triage tag Patient
1. Black C. Extensive third-degree burns
2. Red A. Flail chest
3. Green D. Sprain of the ankle
4. Yellow B. Pelvic fracture

Triage is used to classify the priority of treatment.

It is carried out at the site of the disaster to determine the priority for immediate medical attention, transportation, and admission to the hospital.

Triage includes rapid classification of the injured based on their injuries and the chances of survival with prompt medical intervention. It provides maximum benefit to the greatest number of injured in a disaster situation. It lessens the burden on medical facilities.

The internationally accepted four-color coded system is used commonly:

  • Red - First (I) priority; Immediate attention or transfer; Critical, but likely to survive if treatment is given early
  • Yellow - Second (II) priority; Urgent, Critical, likely to survive if treatment is given within hours
  • Green - Third (III) Non-urgent; Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days
  • Black - Last (0) Unsalvageable; Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help

questions.text: A 21-year-old chronic alcoholic is brought to the emergency room with confusion and tremors. On examination, there is ataxia and ophthalmoplegia. Deficiency of which of the following is responsible for the condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy. It is seen due to the deficiency of thiamine/vitamin B1.

Wernicke's encephalopathy/alcoholic encephalopathy is an acute neurological disorder. Glucose infusions may precipitate Wernicke’s disease in a previously unaffected patient or cause a rapid worsening of an early form of the disease (as in this patient). For this reason, thiamine should be administered to all alcoholic patients requiring parenteral glucose.

The triad is (mnemonic - GOA):

  • Global Confusion
  • Ophthalmoplegia (first symptom to improve with thiamine +dextrose infusion)
  • Ataxia

Alcohol abuse leads to thiamine deficiency by the following mechanisms:

  • Poor nutritional habits
  • Folate deficiency which reduces thiamine absorption from the gastrointestinal tract
  • Direct damage of the intestinal mucosa

The initial treatment in a patient with Wernicke's disease should be emergent thiamine infusion, either IM or IV. This should be given daily until a normal diet is resumed and before treatment with IV glucose. Administration of glucose before thiamine can worsen Wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text: Identify the given fracture:
questions.solution:
The image shows a fracture of the radial styloid process, i.e., Chauffeur fracture. It is caused either by direct trauma to the wrist or traumatic radial deviation of the wrist.

Barton's fracture- Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

Smith's fracture- Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below)

Bumper fracture- fracture of the tibial plateau resulting from impact with automobile bumpers.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to the outpatient department with a history of fever and upper respiratory tract infection for the past few days. On examination, the following is observed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child in the image presented with the classical slapped cheek appearance of erythema infectiosum caused by parvovirus B19. It is also called the fifth disease.

This disease usually presents as a respiratory infection with an erythematous maculopapular rash and arthralgia. This erythematous appearance of the cheeks is called slapped cheek appearance. Children between the age of 5-15 years of age are commonly affected by this disease.

questions.text: A 69-year-old male comes to the medicine OPD with features of loss of interest in various activities, increased jocularity, inappropriate outbursts of rage in social situations for 1 year and memory issues for the past 3 months. For further evaluation, brain biopsy was taken which showed paired helical filaments and ballooned neurons. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of personality changes, loss of social restraint followed by issues of memory, should raise suspicion of frontotemporal dementia (Pick's disease).

  • Pick's disease presents with early personality changes and loss of social restraints initially followed by memory loss. By contrast, Alzheimer's patients present with memory loss first and then develop personality changes.
  • Neuroanatomic findings seen in frontotemporal dementia are atrophy in the frontal and temporal lobes.

Histopathology:

  • Pick cells (swollen neurons) in affected areas of the brain
  • Pick bodies (intraneuronal argentophilic inclusions)

questions.text: A young male presents with reduced sleep, hyperactivity, and elevated mood. He has a history of depression from 4 years back. Which of the following drug should be used for long-term treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of depression, with the current symptoms of mania suggests bipolar disorder. Lithium is a mood stabilizer that is used in the treatment of acute mania and bipolar disorder.

Lithium has a narrow therapeutic index and hence frequent monitoring of serum lithium concentration is necessary for patients who are on lithium therapy.

0.5-0.8 mEq/L is considered ideal for maintenance therapy in patients with bipolar disorder whereas a serum lithium concentration of 0.8-1.2 mEq/L is required in patients with episodes of acute mania.

Initially, lithium toxicity presents with symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, mild diarrhea, and fine tremors. Nervous system toxicity manifests as coarse tremors, ataxia, giddiness, ataxia, motor incoordination, nystagmus, confusion, slurred speech, and hyperreflexia.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman was undergoing cholecystectomy. During the procedure, the resident accidentally advanced the scissors along the superior border of the epiploic foramen causing injury. Which of the following structures is likely to be injured?

questions.text: Which of the following is true about radiotherapy?

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
Vomiting is a late adverse reaction
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant
Radiation-induced skin changes is a reversible adverse effect

questions.solution:
The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the squared distance from the source of radiation. This is known as the inverse square law in radiotherapy.

Inverse square law - the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the squared distance from the source of radiation. This principle is unsuitable for large tumors and has potential risks of radiation exposure to medical staff.

Other options: 

Option B: Vomiting can be an acute (early) adverse reaction to radiation therapy, occurring shortly after treatment.

Option C: Permanent non-dividing cells are more radioresistant than rapidly proliferating cells.

Option D: Not all the adverse effects of radiation therapy are reversible. Some of the adverse effects of radiation therapy, such as fibrosis, radiation-induced skin changes, late radiation enteritis, etc are irreversible.

questions.text: A newborn baby is brought to the OPD with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing Direct laryngoscopy, you notice the following findings.  Which of the following stridor is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the laryngoscopy image showing omega-shaped epiglottis is suggestive of laryngomalacia. Inspiratory stridor is seen in laryngomalacia.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration. This results in inspiratory stridor, a feature typical of laryngomalacia.

It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor is increased on crying but improves (decreases) in the prone position, and worsens during feeding or crying. The cry is normal.

Direct laryngoscopy shows an elongated epiglottis that is curled upon itself, making it appear omega (Ω)-shaped. Other features include floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through narrowed air passages. Stridor may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both

  • Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions. It is often produced in obstructive lesions of the supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

Treatment of Laryngomalacia:

  • Mostly, it self corrects by 2 years of age.
  • Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of the scheme depicted by the logo given below?
questions.solution:
National Health Protection Mission is a component of the Ayushman Bharat scheme.

Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission (AB-NHPM) aims to build a comprehensive need-based health care service and targets to build a 'New India 2022'. Its components are:

  • Creation of 1,50,000 Health and Wellness Centres- these centres will provide Comprehensive Primary Health Care (CPHC), covering both maternal and child health services and non-communicable diseases, including free essential drugs and diagnostic services. 
  • National Health Protection Mission (NHPM) provides health protection cover to poor and vulnerable families, screening for non-communicable diseases, and follow-up of hospitalization cases among others.

Beneficiary Level: 

  • The government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
  • All families listed in the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database as per defined criteria will be covered. No cap on family size and age of members.
  • Priority to a girl child, women, and senior citizens.
  • Free treatment is available at all public and empanelled private hospitals in times of need.
  • Covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.
  • 1,350 medical packages covering surgery, medical and daycare treatments, cost of medicines, and diagnostics.
  • All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment.
  • Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services.
  • Hospitals will not be allowed to charge any additional money from beneficiaries for the treatment.
  • Can reach out for information, assistance, complaints, and grievances to a 24X7 helpline number.

Ayushman Bharat Diwas is being celebrated across the country on April 30.

questions.solution:
The plastic cover of the Foleys catheter is discarded in a Black bag. 

Foley's catheters are packaged in plastic covers to keep them sterile. The plastic cover is not a biomedical waste. It is a general (municipality) waste; hence, it is discarded in the black bag.

questions.text: A patient came to casualty complaining of a severe headache. On examination, there was no focal neurological defect. However, neck rigidity was present. The casualty medical officer ordered an emergency CT which revealed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH).

The most common cause of SAH is trauma. The most common spontaneous cause of SAH is the rupture of berry aneurysms.

It clinically presents as a thunderclap headache with neck rigidity, transient loss of consciousness and no focal neurological deficit. Non-contrast CT shows blood in the basal cistern.

Although sudden headache in the absence of focal neurological symptoms is the hallmark of aneurysmal rupture, focal neurological deficits may occur.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hemorrhage (ICH)

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH): 

  • Source: Arterial bleed
  • MC- Middle meningeal artery 
  • Cause- Trauma 
  • Clinical features: Lucid interval is characteristic 
  • CT – Lentiform opacity 
  • Treatment: A large or rapidly evolving EDH requires surgical evacuation

 

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous bleed 
  • Bridging dural veins 
  • Causes: Trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, shaken baby syndrome 
  • Clinical features
    • Acute SDH: may be associated with lucid interval
    • Chronic SDH: drowsiness, headache
  • CT- crescentic opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

  • Source: Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – Trauma
    • 2nd MC – Rupture of berry aneurysm
  • MC sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery 
  • Clinical features: Thunderclap headache with neck stiffness +/- FND 
  • Investigations:
    • Non-contrast CT brain,
    • CSF xanthochromia (peaks in 2 days and subsides in 2 weeks) 
  • Treatment:
    • Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm,
    • Triple H therapy – hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution to prevent vasospasm

  • Causes:
    • MC – hypertension
    • Trauma, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, bleeding disorders, neoplasms, vascular malformations 
  • MC sites:
    • Putamen (basal ganglia)
    • Thalamus
    • Cerebellum
    • Pons 
  • Treatment:
    • Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP or fresh platelets as required
    • Surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoms >3 cm in size

questions.text: In a hypertensive female, who has the history of GDM, which of the following contraceptives can be used effectively?
questions.solution:
The intrauterine device is a good alternative in patients with GDM plus associated conditions such as co-morbid obesity, hypertension, or dyslipidemia as its a method without potential cardiovascular consequences.

Low dose hormonal contraceptives can be used safely in women with h/o GDM with no associated conditions.

Barrier method, though effective in theory, has a high typical use failure rate, and hence it is not preferred.

Typical use failure rate is the practical failure rate seen in the general population.

For example, barrier methods are very effective when used correctly. However, due to incorrect use, non-compliance, typical use failure rate is high.

Hence, you wouldn't recommend barrier methods as ideal contraceptives.

questions.text: 2 medical students are conducting a study to see the effects of acclimatization at high altitudes. Which of the following will not be seen in the same?
questions.solution:
Hypoventilation is not a part of high-altitude acclimatization.

A person constantly exposed to high altitude slowly acclimatizes to the low PaO2 so that the deleterious effects of the same can be reduced. This occurs mainly via the following mechanisms:

  • Increased pulmonary ventilation
  • Increase RBC and Hb
  • Increased diffusing capacity of the lungs
  • Increased vascularity of the peripheral tissues
  • Increased ability of the tissue cells to use O2, despite low Po2.

Increased pulmonary ventilation: Low PO2 immediately stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors and causes increased alveolar ventilation. The immediate increase may blow off large quantities of CO2, lowering PCO2 and increasing pH which in turn may inhibit the brain stem respiratory centre via peripheral chemoreceptors. But this effect fades away in a few days and the respiratory centre activity returns to normal. Continued exposure to high altitude further increase the ventilation

Increase in red blood cells and hemoglobin concentration: Hypoxia triggers increased RBC production. Hematocrit slowly increases even up to 60%, and blood volume rises and together leading to hemoglobin and myoglobin rise

Increased diffusing capacity after acclimatization: Pulmonary capillary volume expands leading to an increased surface area of diffusion while an increase of pulmonary volume occurs which also increases the surface area of diffusion. Pulmonary arterial pressure rises leading to the opening of normally poorly perfused areas of the lung whereby diffusion further increases

Peripheral circulatory system changes during acclimatization: There is an initial rise in cardiac output to compensate for the low RBC and Hb which later falls to normal once these values rise due to erythropoiesis. Capillary angiogenesis occurs to improve blood flow, especially in the non-pulmonary tissues 

Cellular acclimatization. Changes also occur at the cellular level with an increase in numbers of mitochondria and cellular respiration in organisms living at high altitudes than the ones living at sea level.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient with history of hepatitis and behavioral changes is known to have an inborn error of metabolism. Ocular examination of this patient shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows Kayser–Fleisher ring, which is seen in Wilson’s disease.  

Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF) Ring:

  • KF ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea
  • Characteristically observed in Wilson's disease but is not pathognomonic
  • Does not interfere with vision
  • Present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms
  • Present only in 30–50% of patients diagnosed in the hepatic or presymptomatic state, therefore the absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease.

Wilsons disease:

The autosomal-recessive disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Behavioral disturbances
  • Wing beating tremor
  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Diagnosis:

    • Presence of KF rings
    • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
    • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy
    • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

The gold standard for diagnosis: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays

Treatment: Trientine and Zinc is the first choice of a drug regimen to be used for treating mild hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease.

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient presents with dizziness and palpitations following an alcohol binge. His ECG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ECG are suggestive of atrial fibrillation.

The ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals and no distinct P waves which are the features suggestive of atrial fibrillation.

Atrial fibrillation is a supraventricular tachycardia caused by ectopic foci or small reentry circuits within the atria. It has an atrial rate of 400-600/min and a ventricular rate of 100-160/min. The incidence of AF increases with age and is usually associated with an acute precipitating factor such as acute alcohol intoxication.

questions.text: Which of the following is alcohol-related cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Dilated cardiomyopathy is associated with alcohol consumption. Alcohol is the most common cause of dilated cardiomyopathy in India. It is due to the direct toxic effects of alcohol and its metabolites (acetaldehyde).

Dilated cardiomyopathy is the morphological and functional progressive cardiac dilatation and systolic dysfunction. To be considered DCM, the heart should not have any primary valvular abnormalities.

Causes of DCM include:

Acquired causes:

  • Alcohol is the most common cause in India
  •  Pregnancy:
    • Pregnancy-associated cardiomyopathy (PACM)
    • Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM)
  • Stress-induced: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
  • Drug-induced:
    • Doxorubicin: anthracyclines
    • Trastuzumab 
    • Cyclophosphamide
  • Nutritional deficiency:
    • Beriberi (thiamine),
    • Keshan disease (selenium)
    • Carnitine deficiency
  • Endocrine: Hypo and hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, diabetes mellitus
  • Others:
    • Cobalt toxicity
    • Heavy metals (lead, mercury, arsenic, lithium)
    • Previous history of viral myocarditis

Familial causes (50%): 

    • Mutation in the cardiac myocyte titin gene
    • Haemochromatosis
    • Syndromes: Duchenne muscular dystrophy, Becker’s muscular dystrophy

Chronic heavy consumption of alcohol is associated with systolic and diastolic ventricular dysfunction, dilated cardiomyopathy, systemic hypertension, arrhythmias, and sudden death.

Women appear to be more susceptible to the development of dilated cardiomyopathy at the same level of alcohol consumption as men.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image below:
questions.solution:
The given image shows placenta previa.

The grades of placenta previa are:

  • Type I (Low-lying): The major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the
    lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the os.
  • Type II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the
    internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • Type IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has the following lesion over the face. He complains of bleeding while itching. The most likely diagnosis is ______.
questions.solution:
The image above shows a central ulcer with raised borders and rolled-out edges (rodent ulcer), suggesting a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma (BCC).

BCC is a slow-growing malignant tumor with locally invasive characteristics. It affects the pilosebaceous skin.

Ultraviolet radiation exposure is the strongest predisposing factor. Other risk factors include exposure to arsenic, coal tar, aromatic hydrocarbons, and ionizing radiation. 

BCC mainly affects elderly or middle-aged men with excessive skin exposure, commonly in the age group of 40–80 years and in white-skinned people.

Macroscopically, it is categorized as localized and generalized. Nodular, nodulocystic (nodular and nodulocystic together account for 90% of basal cell carcinoma), pigmented, and nevoid are the localized cancers, while superficial multifocal and superficial spreading, infiltrative, and cicatrizing are the generalized types. The nodular type is described as pearly waxy nodules at the margins. A central depression (umbilication) or ulceration and rolled-out edges are characteristic of BCC.

Sites near the eye, nose, and ear and of size >2 cm are considered to be high risk. Direct invasion at these sites can reach the cranium.

Management is by Mohs microscopic surgery. Non-surgical measures, such as the administration of topical 5-fluorouracil and imiquimod, are useful. Metastasis is extremely rare.

Histopathologic features show ovoid cells in nests with a single palisading layer. The outer layer of cells is in the active division, and thus, incomplete excision can lead to increased aggressiveness.

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhalational agent of choice in a 10-year-old child?
questions.solution:
Induction agent of choice in pediatric anesthesia is sevoflurane.

Although both halothane and sevoflurane provide a smooth induction, sevoflurane appears to have a greater therapeutic index than halothane and is the preferred agent for inhaled induction in pediatric anesthesia.

Isoflurane and desflurane are airway irritants. Hence not used for induction of anesthesia as they can precipitate laryngospasm. These agents are used only during maintenance of anesthesia.

questions.text: A patient with osteomyelitis was found to have  Hb 7 gm/dL and MCV - 55 fL, TIBC - 290 μg/dL, S. Ferritin - 250 μg/L, Transferrin saturation - 20%. The likely diagnosis is ______.
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is anemia of chronic disease as the patient is having low MCV (N: 87-96 fl), low TIBC (N: 300-360μg/dL) with elevated ferritin level (N: 50-200 μg/L), and normal transferrin saturation (N: 25-50%).

Other options:

Option A - Serum ferritin can be used to distinguish iron deficiency anemia from anemia of chronic disease. Iron deficiency anemia will have low serum ferritin. Additionally, high TIBC and low transferrin saturation may be seen in iron deficiency anemia.

Options C & D- Sideroblastic anemia and thalassemia will have a normal TIBC with high transferrin saturation.

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the ER after a road traffic accident. On examination, left-sided hydropneumothorax was noted. Thoracostomy was done and around 1800 ml of blood was drained in 1 hour. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Continue resuscitation for the next 6 Hours
Administer a hemostatic agent through the chest tube

questions.solution:
Given the significant blood loss (1800 ml) and the patient's critical condition, the most appropriate management in this scenario would be an emergency thoracotomy.

A thoracotomy is a surgical procedure in which an incision is made into the chest to access the thoracic cavity. It is performed in critical situations to control bleeding and repair injuries to the chest structures, including the lung and blood vessels.

In this case, the patient's condition is serious due to the combination of pneumothorax, hydrothorax, and a rapid blood loss of 1800 ml in just 1 hour. This level of bleeding suggests a severe injury to blood vessels or vital structures within the chest. Emergency thoracotomy would provide direct access to the bleeding source, allowing for immediate control of bleeding, repair of injuries, and restoration of stable conditions.

Indications for thoracotomy:

  • Initial tube thoracostomy drainage of >1000 ml (penetrating injury) or >1500 ml (blunt injury) of frank blood
  • Ongoing tube thoracostomy drainage of >200 ml/ hr for 3 consecutive hours in non-coagulopathic patients with hemothorax
  • Caked hemothorax despite the placement of two chest tubes
  • Massive air leak from chest tube with inadequate ventilation
  • Open pneumothorax
  • Great vessel injury
  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Cardiac herniation
  • Tracheobronchial injury
  • Esophageal perforation

Other Options:

Option A: Thoracentesis involves the removal of fluid or air from the pleural space using a needle or catheter. However, given the severity of the situation with rapid blood loss, this procedure alone would not adequately address the underlying issues or stop the significant bleeding.

Option B: Continued resuscitation for the next 6 hours is not appropriate in this scenario due to the patient's critical condition and substantial blood loss. Immediate intervention is required to stabilize the patient's condition and address the underlying causes of the blood loss.

Option C: While hemostatic agents can be useful in certain bleeding situations, the rapid blood loss and critical nature of the presented case call for a more immediate and direct approach, such as an emergency thoracotomy, to achieve rapid control of bleeding and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A nulliparous lady, with a BMI of 23, presents with hirsutism. Ultrasonography was done, and the obtained image is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image shows an enlarged ovary with multiple follicles in the periphery. The patient's clinical history and given USG image are indicative of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. The Rotterdam criteria are used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS:

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Menstrual abnormalities (oligomenorrhea/amenorrhea), anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasonography.

Sonographic criteria for polycystic ovaries include ≥ 12 small cysts or an increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both. 

Management:

  • Weight reduction alone is beneficial in mild hirsutism and lifestyle changes (like smoking cessation) are advised in the management of PCOS.
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 μg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism.
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin. Acarbose can be used if metformin is contraindicated
  • Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical options include laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. This is done either by laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores the endocrine levels and improves fertility.

Surgery is indicated only in the case of

  • Failure of medical therapy
  • Hyperstimulation
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: A male patient presented with severe abdominal pain.  On examination, the patient's BP is 80/40 mm hg, and the following finding is noted. CT abdomen is normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image is that of a patient with flank ecchymosis, this is known as the Grey Turner sign and is seen in patients with acute pancreatitis.

Acute pancreatitis is a rapidly progressing inflammatory condition of the pancreas associated with significant mortality and morbidity.

The major risk factors for developing this condition are the presence of gallstones and alcohol abuse.

Patients present with moderate to severe epigastric pain associated with vomiting and loss of appetite. On examination, there is guarding and abdominal tenderness. Rarely, patients may present with Grey Turner and Cullen signs. Grey Turner sign is characterized by flank ecchymosis whereas in Cullen sign patients present with periumbilical ecchymosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is mainly included in the child survival index?
questions.solution:
• Under-5 mortality is the number of deaths under the age of 5 years per 1000 live births.
  • This is the mainly included in the child survival index, which is calculated as (1000 – Under-5 mortality rate)/10.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about section 45 of IEA ?

choices.text: Has the knowledge to draw conclusions from the facts available
Witness Bata may be paid to Doctors even in Criminal Cases

questions.solution:
IEA Section 45 gives information regarding Expert witness. 

The first-hand knowledge Rule is applicable to common witness, not an expert witness.

A common witness is a person who gives evidence about the facts observed or perceived by him based on the first-hand knowledge rule (only facts perceived by him).

Section 45 of the Indian Evidence Act defines an expert witness. An expert witness is one who has acquired special knowledge, skill or experience in any science, art, subject, or profession. He could have acquired such knowledge by practice, observation, or careful studies.

An expert witness may give his opinion

(I) upon facts which are either admitted, or proved by himself or other witnesses at the trial,

(2) on matters of common knowledge, and

(3) on hypothetical questions (questions based on stated assumptions) based thereon.

Hypothetical questions may be asked to extract an opinion from the expert, after he assumes certain facts to be true, describing a specific situation, even though he may not have first-hand knowledge of the actual case.

A doctor's testimony that a certain thing is possible is no evidence at all. A doctor's testimony can only be considered evidence when he states that the conclusion he gives is based on "reasonable medical certainty" (more probable than not in a medical sense) that a fact is true or untrue.

If the witness is a doctor in private practice, he may request the court for conveyance charges and daily allowance according to the Government rules(even in criminal cases). As per law (Section 312 CrPC), he or she will be paid the travel allowances (TA) by the court. This is referred to as "Witness Bata".

A doctor can be both a common and expert witness. When he describes the wounds on the body, he acts as a common witness. But when he says that the wounds were antemortem or post-mortem, or they were suicidal, homicidal, or accidental, or gives opinion regarding the cause of death, he acts as an expert witness.

The chemical examiner is also an expert witness

Also note:

A hostile witness is a person who is supposed to have some interest or motive for concealing a part of the truth or for giving completely false evidence.

questions.text: A 51-year-old lady presents with complaints of a mass in the right breast. The examination finding is shown below. Fixed internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes are palpable on the same side. The mass is malignant without any metastasis. What is the TNM staging in this lady?
questions.solution:
This given clinical scenario in this woman with peau d’orange of the breast suggests her staging is T4b N3b M0

  • Tumour of any size with overlying skin involvement (Peau d'orange appearance) - T4b
  • Ipsilateral fixed internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes - N3b
  • No distant metastasis - M0

The term peau d’orange describes the orange-peel appearance of the skin. The dermal lymphatic blockade gives rise to edema in the breast. The sweat glands and hair follicles get buried due to the edema resulting in a typical orange peel appearance. Infiltration of the ligaments of Cooper results in dimpling of the skin. Infiltration of the lactiferous glands gives rise to retraction of the nipple. Spread into the chest wall results in fixation of the breast into the chest wall. This leads to restricted mobility of the breast
